ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned enough Python 3.0 to begin to ask basic research questions of music corpora. A second unit involved developing fluency with the Music21 program and a final unit involved a brief survey of literature on statistical learning and music.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Too many strengths to list. I have mixed feelings about the lack of any final project. On one hand, it gave me more time to finish my work in other classes, which was very welcome at the time. On the other hand, the course felt somewhat incomplete. We had learned basic Python 3.0, learned how to work with Music21, and read some background lit on statistical learning and modelling. But it felt like these projects never quite converged into anything. It would have been nice to have done even a small project with Music21, or something that would give us a clear model for continuing to do corpus research outside of the class environment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Without hesitation. Even for (especially for?) students without any computing background.
